byline.contributor: Rod Nordland and Mujib Mashal contributed reporting from Kabul, and Taimoor Shah from Kandahar.
byline.original: By DAVID JOLLY and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

abstract: Afghan government fires Helmand Province's deputy governor Mohammad Jan Rasoolyar, who used Facebook to plead for help against Taliban offensive; authorities deem move, made after earlier appeals were ignored, to be excessively reckless; episode reflects social media's ongoing ambivalent relationship to official communications.
lead_paragraph: Complaints on social media by two deputy governors besieged by Taliban, Qaeda and Islamic State fighters were not viewed kindly by the government of President Ashraf Ghani.

headline.main: Afghan Officials, Voicing Security Fears on Facebook, Are Fired for Their Trouble
headline.print_headline: Afghan Officials Voicing Security Concerns Online Are Fired for Efforts

snippet: Complaints on social media by two deputy governors besieged by Taliban, Qaeda and Islamic State fighters were not viewed kindly by the government of President Ashraf Ghani.
